description: VISION 2050 calls for providing and encouraging alternatives to driving alone and ensuring the availability of reliable and competitive transit options. With the adoption of a transit-focused Regional Growth Strategy, complete implementation of a comprehensive, integrated transit system will be critical. The region’s transit  system is built upon the backbone of an extensive bus transit system with an expanding high-capacity transit system.

High-capacity transit in the region is provided by a variety of rail, bus rapid transit and ferry modes, including Sound Transit’s Link light rail, Tacoma Link, and Sounder commuter rail, Seattle’s two streetcar lines and the historic 1962 monorail, Community Transit’s Swift and King County Metro’s RapidRide bus rapid transit services, and multimodal and passenger-only ferry services provided by the Washington State Ferries, Pierce County Ferries and King County.

There are eight agencies that provide fixed-route transit service in the Central Puget Sound Region. Links to each of these agencies is provided on this page. These agencies coordinate their long-range planning efforts with PSRC and the key priorities in each agency's long range plan are incorporated in the Regional Transportation Plan.

This dashboard is updated throughout the calendar year and is based on three key sources of data.

  • National Transit Data (NTD) Monthly Performance Data
  • Spring & Fall service change data via agency GTFS
  • Washington State Office of Financial Management Small Area Estimates Program
The dashboard pages are organized by the level of summarization that an individual might be interested in, starting at the regional level and going down to summarizations of data by transit stops. The pages can be accessed by the links along the top of the dashboard. The key metrics included in the dashboard include boardings, revenue-hours, revenue-miles and boardings per hour. The six different dashboard pages are:

  • Region: Summarizes the four key transit performance metrics for all modes and operators in King, Kitsap, Pierce and Snohomish counties.
  • Mode: Summarizes the four key transit performance metrics by transit modes for all operators in King, Kitsap, Pierce and Snohomish counties.
  • Operator: Summarizes the four key transit performance metrics by operator for all transit modes.
  • Type: Summarizes the number of people that live within either 1/4 or 1/2 mile of a transit stops by type of transit and population of interest.
  • Frequency: Summarizes the number of people that live within either 1/4 or 1/2 mile of a transit stops by number of transit trips per hour and population of interest.
  • Routes: A map of transit routes color coded by transit type from the latest service change data.
The Region, Mode and Operator pages are based on NTD data and are updated monthly, generally by the 15th of the month but dependent on the latest release of data by the Federal Transit Administration. The Type, Frequency, and Routes pages are updated twice per year, once in the fall after the Fall service change and once in the spring after the spring service change.

The Central Puget Sound had one of the fastest growing transit systems in the US before the Pandemic. Like many regions across the country, transit in the Central Puget Sound region continues to rebound from pandemic lows in 2021.
Commute mode by people of color.

• Transit usage continues to grow post pandemic.

  • Transit service continues to be restored and was about 85% of 2019 levels in 2024.

  • Recovery of Transit boardings has lagged the recovery of transit service.

• Light rail ridership has surpassed pre-pandemic levels.

  • Commuter Rail and vanpool ridership continue to be impacted the most by post-pandemic work travel patterns.

  • Ferry boardings increased 3% in the past year and are over 81% of pre-pandemic levels.

• With recent extensions, light rail hours are over 60% higher than they were in 2019.

  • Bus hours continue to be restored and were at 86% of 2019 levels in the first 8 months of 2024.

  • Ferry service has neared 93% of pre-pandemic service levels.

• With recent extensions, light rail miles are 58% higher than they were in 2019.

  • Commuter rail service grew in 2024 and is at 75% of 2019 revenue-miles.

  • Vanpool usage is about half of pre-pandemic levels.

• Ferries carry the most passengers per hour of any transit mode, exceeding 156 boardings per hour in 2024.

  • Light Rail boardings per hour were down slightly in the first 8 months of 2024, due in part to ridership declines on Street Car routes.

  • Bus boardings per hour have grown the most in the first 8 months of 2024.

• Everett Transit carried more passengers in the first 8 months of 2024 than it did in 2019.

  • Sound Transit boardings have exceeded 27 million in the first 8 months of 2024, second most in the region.

  • Kitsap transit boardings were over 80% of pre-pandemic levels so far this year.

• With recent extensions, Sound Transits total revenue-hours are higher than they were in 2019.

  • Washington State Ferries have provided 87% of 2019 revenue-hours so in 2024.

  • King County Metro revenue hours were 85% of 2019 levels in 2024.

• With recent extensions, Sound Transits total revenue-hours are higher than they were in 2019.

  • Washington State Ferries have provided 87% of 2019 revenue-hours so in 2024.

  • King County Metro revenue hours were 85% of 2019 levels in 2024.

• Washington State Ferries carry the most passengers per hour, exceeding 179 boardings per hour in 2024.

  • Pierce Transit ridership-per-hour has increased since 2021 and is at 11 boardings per hour so far in 2024.

  • Community Transit riders per-hour are nearing 12 in 2024.

• A higher share of People of color, who data show tend to use transit more, live closer to transit than the regional average.

  • The share of Equity Focus Area populations living close to high capacity transit modes has increased since 2019.

  • The number of people living close to all transit in 2024 was slightly lower than 2019.

Insights & Analysis

  • Almost half of people of color live within 1/2 miles of a transit stop that has at least 4 trips an hour serving it.

  • Approximately 650,000 people live within half a mile of a transit stop that has a bus going somewhere every five minutes.

  • The share of people living close to all transit stops with a trip every 7-1/2 minutes was the same in the fall of 2024 as it was in 2019.
